page.title: 17LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: {1953.}The village looked very much as it does now,except that the village green was used as gardens.Large lime trees stood inside it's North wall with irish Yews planted between.These gardens became less well tended as the inhabitants became aged,and when the National Trust took over in 1958 this central area was laid out as a Green. So much had the numbers of estate workers dwindled in the early 1950's, there were almost no young people in Cambo,and for a considerable time no children,except those of visitors.But as the National Trust increased their staff,the village gradually became the home of young families with a lively set of village children. The school children used to come to the village hall for thei dinner,until the large new hall and kitchen were built on to the school in the 1970's.
